intro: Mentha gintliana, commonly known as the Ethiopian mint, is a perennial herb native to the highlands of Ethiopia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its square stems and aromatic leaves. The plant typically grows to a height of about 30–60 cm, with opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves that are often covered in fine hairs. Its small, pale blue to purple flowers appear in whorled clusters, and it is valued for its aromatic properties and traditional medicinal uses. Mentha gintliana thrives in cool, moist environments and is often found in mountainous regions with well-drained soil.
